title: Hello World
text:
This is where I try to post regularly, for example my fleeting notes, literature notes, reference notes, permanent notes, etc. during the day.
A new start which is marked by the day 15-May-2023. But there are notes that predate 15th of May, because the habit goes way back.


 Back to top

title: Good Enough
text:
The perfect is the enemy of the good, often attributed to Voltaire. Yet we strive for the perfect and fail to achieve simple results. Perfectionism gets in the way of doing good stuff, ironically progress is hindered.



 Back to top

title: Anger & Wholesome Way
text:
Anger hurts you instead of the problem that generates it.
Thus, try to maintain a merely disappointed and annoyed attitude.
A more wholesome way to make a change, instead of becoming minimalist, vegan or move into a tiny house.



 Back to top

title: Cheat Sheet
text:
pwd to see what the current working directory is.
ls to list directory contents.
cd foo to change to the foo sub-directory of your working directory.
cd .. to move up to the parent of the working directory.
mkdir foo to create a sub-directory called foo in the working directory.
up-arrow to go back through your command history.
tab to complete directories and file names.

title: Cheat Sheet
text:
pwd to see what the current working directory is.

cd foo to change to the foo sub-directory of your working directory.

title: Cheat Sheet
text:
Pandoc
To convert md to HTML, use this command:
pandoc test1.md -f markdown -t html -s -o test1.html
To convert a whole directory of files from md to HTML in linux or OSX:
for f in *.md; do pandoc "$f" -s -o "${f%.md}.html"; done
HTML with table of contents, CSS, and custom footer:
pandoc -s --toc -c pandoc.css -A footer.html MANUAL.txt -o MANUAL.html

title: Cheat Sheet
text:
Quarto
To render all *.qmd files in posts to generate HTML in docs, use this command in RStudio Terminal (do not use Build>Render):
quarto render

title: Cheat Sheet
text:
Server
Start Python server:
python3 -m http.server 
Go to the URL
localhost:8000

title: Fake News
text:

title: The Road to Reality
text: The purpose of the book is to convey to the reader some feeling for understating the universe. The inherent difficulty in such endeavor has led us in many false directions hence we can learn caution from this book in addition to the primary goal of the book by Penrose (2006)

title: PechaKucha & Haiku
text:
Dytham and Klein developed a new form of presenting they have dubbed ‚Äúpecha kucha‚Äù (Japanese for ‚Äúchatter‚Äù). This form of presentation style has a simple set of rules‚Äîexactly 20 slides displayed for 20 seconds each. Say what you need to say in six minutes and forty seconds.
See this link.

text:

title: PechaKucha & Haiku
text:
What is a Haiku?
The haiku is a Japanese poetic form that consists of three lines, with five syllables in the first line, seven in the second, and five in the third. The haiku developed from the hokku, the opening three lines of a longer poem known as a tanka. The haiku became a separate form of poetry in the 17th century.
The haiku began gaining mainstream recognition outside Japan in the early 20th century. In the English-speaking world, the form was popularized by Imagists such as Ezra Pound and later by Beat poets such as Allen Ginsberg.
See this link.

title: Killing Commendatore
text: A story of a painter who did portrait commissions for financial stability and later spent several months in solitude to paint as he pleased. Loaded with Murakami characters and wisdom, the book inspires to pursue some form of art for one‚Äôs own satisfaction, live in solitude, get better at what one does and make art. Murakami (2019)

text:

Also see Zanshin

title: Compromises
text:
I tried several options:

Static site generators, Jekyll-based options and Python scripts
Simple html files using Notepad++ to build a website to hold my notes

Then I‚Äôm back to .md files using Zettlr, because it supports:

Math typesetting i.e.¬†good \(\LaTeX\) support.
Easy input of more commands in .md than in .html using Notepad++
Easy .html and .pdf generation
Citation built-in with Zotero

But I discovered Quarto which is a scientific and technical publishing system utilizing Pandoc. It does everything Zettlr does but in style. But Zettlr is still best for raw note-taking.

title: n Rules for Life
text:
Accept things as they are whether agreeable or disagreeable. Suzuki (2020)
Never lose sight of ultimate purpose, your physical and mental health: You‚Äôre sane and breathing this minute and may be gone forever the next minute. (Unknown, probably Aurelius) Maintain your physical fitness and sanity.
Practice any art, music, singing, dancing, acting, drawing, painting, sculpting, poetry, fiction, essays, reportage, no matter how well or badly, not to get money and fame, but to experience becoming, to find out what‚Äôs inside you, to make your soul grow. ‚Äì Kurt Vonnegut
No hurry, no pause: When you rush, time shrinks. When you‚Äôre relaxed, time expands. This is true even though it‚Äôs very hard for the mind to get. When you‚Äôre relaxed and doing something willingly, you‚Äôre participating in life. (Jon Schreiber, Breema Center)
You are what you think: Keep an untroubled spirit; for all things must bow to Nature‚Äôs Law Aurelius (2003)
Reflect on what you‚Äôve read and written: Information becomes knowledge by reflection. Reflection cultivates intuition. abundant intuition makes up for lack of information thereby enabling you operate where your knowledge is limited. (Unknown)
Give your attention proportioned to the merits of the case: Sometimes full attention, sometimes none. (Unknown)
Focus not so much on words but on actual behavior. (Don‚Äôt watch his mouth, watch his hands. ‚Äì Adler‚Äôs dictum).
Do not try to stay on top of things (you cannot). Instead try to get to the bottom of things. (This kind of success, while not guaranteed, will be more fulfilling than the former).
It is more important to invest in good people than in good ideas. (bet on the jockey not the horse).
Work expands to fill the time available for its completion (Parkinson‚Äôs law).
Perceive those things which cannot be seen (e.g.¬†pay attention even to trifles). And do nothing which is of no use. (Miyamoto Musashi)
One who makes a show of valor is hated by others, even he achieves something, it is not praised but denied. (Kumazawa Banzan)
In the short term, you are as good as your intensity. In the long term, you are only as good as your consistency.
We read the same facts differently. For an optimist philosopher the universe spells victory, for a pessimist, defeat. (William James, from Pragmatism and Other Writings).
Roughly 80% of outcomes come from 20% of causes (see Pareto principle).








Note




Revised on 2023-June-25
Revised on 2023-June-23
Revised on 2023-May-16
Revised on 2023-February-10
Revised on 2023-February-07







 Back to topReferences

Aurelius, Marcus. 2003. Meditations: A New Translation. Translated by Gregory Hays. Revised ed. edition. New York: Modern Library.


Suzuki, Shunryu. 2020. Zen Mind, Beginner‚Äôs Mind: 50th Anniversary Edition. Anniversary edition. Boulder: Shambhala.

title: Effort vs Results
text:
Do not confuse effort with results.
Just because you put in the effort does not mean you‚Äôll get the desired result.
A lot of effort gets undone long before results are felt. Going to the gym is undone if you eat poorly. Focusing only on work gets undone by the inevitable health and relationship issues that come from under-investment. When we try to speed up the outcome, our lack of patience undoes the result.






Caution



Results are accumulated in drops but lost in buckets.Make sure you‚Äôre not undoing the things you‚Äôre trying to accomplish.



Sometimes the hardest decisions a person can make will most likely lead to the best outcomes. - Colleen Hoover.

üÜö



 Back to top

title: Right Practice: Posture & Breathing
text:
Zazen practice is the direct expression of our true nature. Suzuki (2020)


It‚Äôs not for obtaining the right state of mind, the posture itself is the right state of mind.

Keep your spine straight.
In posture, you‚Äôre not one or not two. Body and mind is both.
Our body and mind shouldn‚Äôt be wobbling or wandering, right posture will bring you a steady state. But it‚Äôs not about right state of mind, the posture itself is the right state of mind.
Keep right posture in everything you do.
When you try to attain something, your mind starts to wander about somewhere else. When you do not try to attain anything, you have your own body and mind right here.
When we have our body and mind in order, everything else will exist in the right place, in the right way.
Enlightenment is not some good feeling or some particular state of mind. The state of mind that exists when you sit in the right posture is, itself, enlightenment.




When we practice zazen our mind always follows or breathing, concentrate on your breathing, the fundamental activity of universal being.

title: On Human Stupidity
text:
Non-stupid people always underestimate the damaging power of stupid people. In particular, they constantly forget that at all times and places and under any circumstances to deal and/or associate with stupid people infallibly turns out to be a costly mistake. Cipolla and Taleb (2021)
Helpless people are through their own nature will fail to recognize how dangerous stupid people are. Intelligent people and bandits also are tempted to believe or associate themselves with a stupid individual. However this can have a disastrous effects:

It is based on a complete misunderstanding of the essential nature of stupidity,
It gives the stupid person added scope for the exercise of his gifts.

title: On Human Stupidity
text:
Avoid Stupid People
Because of the erratic behavior of the stupid, one cannot foresee all the stupid‚Äôs actions and reactions, and before long one will be pulverized by the unpredictable moves of the stupid partner.

title: On Human Stupidity
text:
History
In public and private life, innumerable individuals have failed to understand the Fourth Law. The failure has caused incalculable losses in the history of mankind.

title: The Case for Daydreaming
text: In neuroscience, the¬†default mode network¬†(DMN), also known as the¬†default network,¬†default state network is best known for being active when a person is not focused on the outside world and the brain is at¬†wakeful rest, such as during¬†daydreaming and¬†mind-wandering. It can also be active during detailed thoughts related to external task performance. Other times that the DMN is active include when the individual is thinking about others, thinking about themselves, remembering the past, and planning for the future. (See Default mode network)

title: The Case for Daydreaming
text: In neuroscience, the¬†default mode network¬†(DMN), also known as the¬†default network,¬†default state network is best known for being active when a person is not focused on the outside world and the brain is at¬†wakeful rest, such as during¬†daydreaming and¬†mind-wandering. It can also be active during detailed thoughts related to external task performance. Other times that the DMN is active include when the individual is thinking about others, thinking about themselves, remembering the past, and planning for the future. (See Default mode network)

title: The Case for Daydreaming
text:
Mind-wandering
Mind-wandering is a broad term with no currently universal definition. According to McMillan, Kaufmann and Singer (2013) mind-wandering consists of 3 different subtypes: positive constructive daydreaming, guilty fear of failure, and poor attentional control. Whereas Smallwood and Schooler (2015) suggest that mind-wandering consists of thoughts that are task-unrelated and stimulus-independent. In general, a folk explanation of mind-wandering could be described as the experience of thoughts not remaining on a single topic for a long period of time, particularly when people are engaged in an attention-demanding task. (See Mind-wandering)

title: The Case for Daydreaming
text:
Key Takeaways from UBC Magazine
In a cumulative and worrying way, the smart phones might be making us stupid.
This is no mere speculation. On the increasingly rare occasion when we let our minds wander, the blood in our brains rushes to what is called the default network.
The default network: a vital support centre for spontaneous thought, a creative space that helps us through our thoughts and experiences. But goal driven thinking happens in another part of the brain, disconnects us from the fullness of our experience. (See Kalina Christoff)

title: Pareto Distribution
text:
The 80-20 Rule
While not as well-known as the bell-shaped Normal (Gaussian) distribution, the Pareto distribution is a powerful tool for modeling a variety of real-life phenomena. It is named after the Italian economist Vilfredo Pareto (1848-1923), who developed the distribution in the 1890s as a way to describe the allocation of wealth in society. He famously observed that 80% of society‚Äôs wealth was controlled by 20% of its population, a concept now known as the ‚ÄúPareto Principle‚Äù or the ‚Äú80-20 Rule‚Äù. Source.
Also see Pareto efficiency and Parkinson‚Äôs Law.




 Back to top

title: Random Notes
text:
Vacation
Vacation is when you forget what day it is and I can hardly tell what day it was when we were travelling to Tofino.

Relaxing brings weakness, when done by a muscle; but brings strength, when done by a person.‚Äù ‚Äï Mokokoma Mokhonoana

title: Random Notes
text:
Focusing Illusion
The idea that you can be focused on a particular aspect of life, so much so that you can believe that your whole happiness depends on it. In having a focusing illusion, you create your own reason for feeling unhappy. Mogi (2018)
If unhappiness is a vacuum in which the required element is absent, the vacuum is created by the biased imagination of the subject. There is no absolute formula for happiness - each unique condition of life can serve as the foundation for happiness in its own unique way. Mogi (2018)

title: Random Notes
text:
How to Fix?
From Seth‚Äôs blog (link)

One reason we have so much trouble fixing chronic degenerative conditions is that we need to remove elements before we can start building new functions. If we simply put effort on top of a shaky foundation, it‚Äôll all be wasted. The best way forward might be to take a few steps back.

title: Human Stupidity
text:
Reasonable people have q hard time imagining unreasonable behavior. A stupid person is one who causes harm to others while gaining nothing and even harming himself in doing so. (See Cipolla and Taleb (2021))
A stupid person will harass you with no reason. You have no rational way of telling if and when and how and why the stupid creature attacks. When confronted with a stupid individual, you‚Äôre completely at his mercy. Because the stupid person‚Äôs actions do not conform to the rules of rationality. From all that proceeds:

You‚Äôre caught by surprise.
You cannot build a rational defense because the attack lacks any rational structure.

title: Human Stupidity
text:
Frequency Distribution
Most people do not act consistently, they will act intelligently one time and helplessly another. Stupid people normally show perfect consistency in all fields of human endeavors.
Cipolla and Taleb (2021) classify four types of people, comments are mine:

Helpless: Identify and help the helpless.
Intelligent: Identify and surround yourself with intelligent people.
Bandit: Identify and utilize bandits with great caution when circumstances demand it.
Stupid: Identify and isolate stupid people from your daily life, especially at work.

title: Human Stupidity
text:
Stupidity and Power
Damaging potential of stupidity is a function of:

Genetic factors and the resulting inheritance
The position of power and consequences

title: Human Stupidity
Human Stupidity
text:
Footnotes


Fraction of stupid people within a population is denoted by the symbol \(\sigma\). No specific numerical value is assigned as a numerical estimate would likely be an underestimate.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Zanshin
text:
Zanshin is a word used commonly throughout Japanese martial arts to refer to a state of relaxed alertness. Literally translated, zanshin means ‚Äúthe mind with no remainder.‚Äù In other words, the mind completely focused on action and fixated on the task at hand.¬†Zanshin is being constantly aware of your body, mind, and surroundings without stressing yourself. It is an effortless vigilance.
In practice, though, zanshin has an even deeper meaning. Zanshin is choosing to live your life intentionally and acting with purpose rather than mindlessly falling victim to whatever comes your way.
We can carry this philosophy into many areas of life.

Writing:¬†The battle does not end when you publish a book. It ends when you consider yourself a finished product, when you lose the vigilance needed to continue improving your craft.
Fitness:¬†The battle does not end when you hit a PR. It ends when you lose concentration and skip workouts or when you lose perspective and overtrain.







Important



The enemy of improvement is neither failure nor success.¬†The enemy of improvement is boredom, fatigue, and lack of concentration. The enemy of improvement is a lack of commitment to the process because the process is everything.


Also see this and¬†Zanshin

title: Truth-default Theory
text:
Proposed by philosophers and recently supported by experimental psychologists, there‚Äôs considerable evidence showing that if we hear something, we assume it to be true. This tendency is sometimes referred to as truth-default theory.

Truth Bias
Truth bias is people‚Äôs inclination towards believing, to some degree, the communication of another person, regardless of whether or not that person is actually lying or being untruthful It is human nature to believe communication is honest, which in turn makes humans highly vulnerable to deception. Consequently, a person‚Äôs ability to detect deception is weakened, particularly when the source of deception is unfamiliar. As long as a person already has the perception that everything they are told is true, they are still considered to be truth-biased. (See ‚ÄúTruth Bias‚Äù).




 Back to top

title: The Basic Laws of Human Stupidity
text: The basic laws assert that Cipolla and Taleb (2021)

title: Negative Utility
text:
You need a book, a pen, and time. More tools give you negative utility. They won‚Äôt make the work go faster. But they will consume as much time as you are willing to waste. Productivity advice
Do the work.
That‚Äôs all the productivity advice you need, and the only useful productivity advice you‚Äôre ever going to get.
You can direct your attention to a million optimization‚Äî email, meetings, notes, calendar, time tracking, goals, to-do lists, time estimates, prioritization frameworks, quantified self sensors, analytics, apps, documents, journaling.
But don‚Äôt. Ignore all this, and do the work. When you do the work, everything else optimizes itself.
Source unknown.



 Back to top

title: On Human Stupidity
text: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person and they are more dangerous then bandits. The worst consequences of this at macro level is that the algebraic sum of the stupid individuals in a group or society at large will affect the wealth and welfare of the society. Cipolla and Taleb (2021)

title: On Human Stupidity
text: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person and they are more dangerous then bandits. The worst consequences of this at macro level is that the algebraic sum of the stupid individuals in a group or society at large will affect the wealth and welfare of the society. Cipolla and Taleb (2021)

title: On Human Stupidity
text:
Macro Analysis
Bandits: The net result of the action is simply the transfer of positives and negatives. The society as whole neither better nor worse off. If all members of a society were perfect bandits, the society would remain stagnant but there would be no major disaster.
Stupids: They cause losses to other people with no gain on their own account. The society as a whole is impoverished. (See the First Basic Law \(\sigma\), the fraction of stupid is a constant and the Second Basic Law, \(\sigma\) is not affected by time, space, race, class or any other sociocultural or historical variable).

title: On Human Stupidity
text:
Essential Points
In a poorly performing society:

the stupid are allowed by the other members to become more active and take more actions.
there is a decline in the composition of non-stupid people, for example Hs and Bs population will decline the society.

Therefore:

In a group, society or country moving uphill, intelligent people manage to keep the \(\sigma\) fraction at bay and produce enough gains to make progress a certainty.
In a group, society or country moving downhill, the \(\sigma\) fraction is still the same but the composition of non-stupid people increases the destructive power and makes decline a certainty. This is the direction to Hell.

Time is the most important asset.
Time does not equal money.
Time equals life.
And you only have one chance to make it right.
Every human being is fighting a battle inside themselves.
It‚Äôs your obligation to help and inspire them.
Regardless of what you do,
you can always inspire others to do good.
Nobody is better than you.
And you‚Äôre not better than anybody else.
Be humble.
Being in the comfort zone is wonderful,
but nothing ever grows there.
Keep studying.
Keep creating.
Haters will come if you have the audacity to build something new.
Don‚Äôt let them define you.
Don‚Äôt let them stop you.
Just block them and keep going.
Don‚Äôt expect others to make you happy.
You are the only one responsible for your happiness.
Don‚Äôt wait until Friday to enjoy life.
Joy should be present in everything you do.
Be kind to your parents.
They gave up many things for you.
Having millions of people admiring you is worthless,
if you‚Äôre not admired by your own family.
Don‚Äôt fear the unknown.
Fear knowing everything.
Life is too damn short and every day counts.
Do what you wanna do and do it now.
Time doesn‚Äôt stop.
Time doesn‚Äôt wait.

Credits:
Based on ‚ÄúTick-tock. Tick-tock.‚Äù by Zeno & Carol




 Back to top

title: Novelist as a Vocation
text: Novelist as a Vocation by Murakami (2022)

title: Novelist as a Vocation
text: Novelist as a Vocation by Murakami (2022)

title: Novelist as a Vocation
section: Excerpt. ¬© Reprinted by permission. All rights reserved1.
text:
Excerpt. ¬© Reprinted by permission. All rights reserved1.
Writing fiction is an entirely personal process that takes place in a closed room. Shut away in a study, you sit at a desk and (in most cases) create an imaginary story out of nothing and put it in the form of writing. The formless and subjective is transformed into something tangible and objec-tive (or at least something that seeks to be objective). Defined sim-ply, this is the day-to-day work we novelists perform.I‚Äôm sure there are many people who will say, ‚ÄúBut wait, I don‚Äôt have anything like a study.‚Äù The same was true for me when I started out writing‚ÄîI had nothing resembling a study to work in. In my tiny apartment near the Hatonomori Hachiman Shrine in Sendagaya (in a building that‚Äôs since been torn down) I sat at the kitchen table late at night after my wife had gone to bed, scratching away with a pen on Japanese-style manuscript paper. That‚Äôs how I¬†wrote my first two novels, Hear the Wind Sing and Pinball, 1973. ‚ÄúKitchen-table‚Äù fiction is what I‚Äôve dubbed these early works.

When I first started writing Norwegian Wood, I wrote at caf√©s in various places in Greece, on board ferry boats, in the wait-ing lobbies of airports, in shady spots in parks, and at desks in cheap hotels. Hauling around oversized, four-hundred-character- per-page Japanese manuscript paper was too much, so in Rome I bought a cheap notebook (the kind we used to call college-ruled notebooks) and wrote the novel down in tiny writing with a dis-posable Bic pen. I still had to contend with noisy caf√©s, wobbly tables that made writing difficult, coffee spilling on the pages, and at night in my hotel room when I‚Äôd go over what I‚Äôd written, some-times there would be couples getting all hot and heavy beyond the paper-thin walls separating my room from the room next door. Things weren‚Äôt easy, in other words. I can smile at these memories now, but at the time it was all pretty discouraging. I had trouble finding a decent place to live, and moved all over Europe, all the while continuing to work on my novel. And I still have that thick old notebook, with its coffee stains (or whatever they are; I‚Äôm not really sure about some of them).

Wherever a person is when he writes a novel, it‚Äôs a closed room, a portable study. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to say.

title: The Art of Practicing
text: The Art of Practicing by Bruser and Menuhin (1999) contains wisdom and practical advise. Performance as a practice see page 216.

title: The Art of Practicing
text: The Art of Practicing by Bruser and Menuhin (1999) contains wisdom and practical advise. Performance as a practice see page 216.

title: The Art of Practicing
text:
A Ten-Step Approach

Stretch
Settle down in your environment: Be present, correct posture, breathing.
Tune into your heart: Recalling profound feelings is how to tune into your heart.
Use your body in a comfortable and natural way. Mechanics, habits and emotions‚Ä¶
Follow your curiosity as you practice.
Recognize three styles of struggle:

Overstated passion, in which we cling to the music.
Avoidance, in which we resist dealing with the music.
Aggression, in which we attack the music.

Drop your attitudes and be simple.
Apply three listening techniques:

Sing the notes and lines.
Place your attention on the vibrations.
Place your attention on each sound as it resonates in the space around you.

Organize notes into groups, phrases, and textures.
Place your attention on the sensations of touch and movement.

title: The Art of Practicing
text:
Key Takeaways

Relax, tension is your worst enemy
Hear the music you‚Äôre playing
Be gentle to yourself
Do not over practice, short mindful work is superior to long laboured practice sessions.

title: The Art of Practicing
text:
Miscellaneous Notes

Swing the music instead of sounding like sewing machine. Group notes and play them by creating a forward motion.
Focus on more on the sensations of touch and movement and use your vision mainly to check that what you feel is in accord with what you see. Bruser & Menuhin (1999, p.¬†200).
Think the sound you make. Then discover the sensation your brain has created for you. Bruser & Menuhin (1999, p.¬†201).
